'''''Cantharellus formosus''''', commonly known as the '''pacific golden chanterelle''', is a [[fungus]] native to the [[Pacific Northwest]] region of [[North America]]. It is a member of the genus ''[[Cantharellus]]'' along with other popular edible [[chanterelle]]s.  It was distinguished from the similar ''[[Cantharellus cibarius|C. cibarius]]'' of [[Europe]] in the 1990s.<ref name=red97/>  It is orange to yellow, meaty and funnel-shaped. On the underside of the smooth cap, it has gill-like ridges that run down onto its stipe, which tapers down seamlessly from the cap. The false gills often have a pinkish hue. It has a mild, sweet odor.<ref name=mexp/>  It is solitary to gregarious in [[conifer]]ous forests, fruiting from July to December.<ref name=ehlers10/>

The pacific golden chanterelle is the most important commercially harvested ''Cantharellus'' species in the Pacific Northwest.<ref name=ehlers10/><ref name=pilz03/>  This chanterelle has been designated [[List of Oregon state symbols|Oregon's state mushroom]], due to its economic value and abundance.<ref name=orla/>

==Description==
[[Basidiocarp|Fruiting bodies]] of ''C. formosus'' range from {{convert|2|-|14|cm|in|abbr=on}} wide, with [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] colors varying depending on light levels and weather.  In dry weather, the cap is medium orange yellow to light yellow brown, but wet weather may brighten the cap to brilliant to soft orange yellow.  In low light conditions, caps may not develop the yellow pigmentation, resulting in salmon to rosy buff colors.  The [[hymenium|false gills]] may be yellow, salmon, buff, or even whitish depending on conditions, but are usually paler than the cap.  The [[stipe (mycology)|stem]] is colored similarly to the cap, and is either equal-width or tapering downwards.  The spore print is a yellowish white color.<ref name=red97/>

==Taxonomy==
[[File:Cantharellus formosus 28084.jpg|thumb|left|Pinkish hue on false gills of ''C. formosus'']]

[[E. J. H. Corner]] formally described ''C. formosus'' in 1966 from specimens collected on [[Vancouver Island]] in 1938.<ref name=corner66/>  Despite this publication, the name ''C. cibarius'' continued to be used to refer to golden chanterelles in the Pacific Northwest.  In 1997, Redhead et al. re-examined Corner's specimens, returned to the type locale, and collected new specimens, confirming the identity of ''C. formosus''.<ref name=red97/>  [[Molecular phylogenetics|DNA analysis]] has since confirmed the species-level rank of ''C. formosus''.<ref name=mon06/>

==Distribution==
''C. formosus'' has been reported from [[British Columbia]] to [[California]], and is particularly abundant in the [[conifer]] forests of [[Washington (U.S. state)|Washington]] and [[Oregon]].  It forms a [[mycorrhiza|mycorrhizal association]] with [[Pseudotsuga menziesii|Douglas-fir]] and [[Tsuga heterophylla|western hemlock]], and has been shown to be more common in younger (40- to 60-year-old) forests than in [[old-growth forest]]s.<ref name=amm09/><ref name=dun06/>

==Similar species==
[[File:Cantharellus formosus 121420.jpg|thumb|right|Yellow-brown specimens of ''C. formosus'']]

Several other species of chanterelle may be found in western North America:<ref name=pnwkey/>
*''[[Cantharellus californicus|C. californicus]]'' — large size, associated with oaks in California
*''[[Cantharellus cascadensis|C. cascadensis]]'' — bright yellow fading to white in center of cap, may have bulbous base of stem
*''[[Cantharellus cibarius|C. cibarius]]'' var. ''roseocanus'' — brilliant orange-yellow color without pinkish hues, false gills not paler than cap
*''[[Cantharellus subalbidus|C. subalbidus]]'' — whitish overall color

Additionally, ''[[Hygrophoropsis aurantiaca]]'', ''[[Chroogomphus|Chroogomphus tomentosus]]'', and species in the genera ''[[Craterellus]]'', ''[[Gomphus (fungus)|Gomphus]]'', ''[[Omphalotus]]'', and ''[[Polyozellus]]'' may have a somewhat similar appearance to ''C. formosus''.
